greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Length of longest sequence of distinct nonzero squares summing to n, or 0 if no such sequence exists.
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
P. T. Bateman, A. J. Hildebrand and G. B. Purdy, Sums of distinct squares, Acta Arithmetica 67 (1994), pp. 349-380.
example: 2 and 3 are not sums of distinct squares, so a(2) = 0 and a(3) = 0.
maple: N:= 100: # to get a(1) to a(N)
for j from 1 to M do
for n from sj(j)+1 to N do A[n,j]:= -infinity od:
for n from 1 to j^2-1 do A[n,j]:= A[n,j-1] od:
for n from j^2 to min(sj(j),N) do A[n,j]:= max(A[n,j-1],1+A[n-j^2,j-1]) od:
mathematica: For[n = s[j] + 1, n <= Nt, n++, A[n, j] = -Infinity];
For[n = j^2, n <= Min[s[j], Nt], n++, A[n, j] = Max[A[n, j-1], 1+A[nj^2, j-1]]]
Table[A[n, M] /. DirectedInfinity[-1] -> 0, {n, 1, Nt}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 04 2019, after _Robert Israel_ *)
results.author: _Robert Israel_, Oct 07 2014
